Okay, so I need to figure out if the author is in the wrong here. Let me read through the situation again carefully.

The author is trying to make plans with his girlfriend. She initially says she doesn't want to have sex that night because she wants to just hang out and do other things. The author agrees, and they start planning dinner and other activities. The author suggests playing video games, which the girlfriend says she wants to do something together instead. The author says he really wants to play games because of midterms and hasn't been able to. The girlfriend then offers that if he doesn't play games at all today, they can have sex that night. The author initially agrees but then clarifies that playing before she arrives is okay, but she insists that he can't play any at all. When she says they can just not have sex then, the author gets upset, saying she's using sex as a power play. The girlfriend argues it's just an offer, and they're not talking now.

So, the key points here are about consent, mutual respect, and power dynamics in the relationship. The author feels that the girlfriend is using sex as a reward to get him to comply with her terms (not playing games all day). The girlfriend says it's an offer, not a power play. 

In healthy relationships, both partners should feel that their needs are being considered without using conditional rewards or punishments. If one person is using something like sex as a way to get the other to do what they want, that can be seen as a power imbalance. However, if both parties are comfortable with the terms, even if it's a trade-off, it might not be a problem. But in this case, the girlfriend's offer is conditional on the author giving up something (not playing games before their time together) to have sex. The author feels that the condition is unnecessary because the time before she arrives is his own, and the benefit (sex) is only one-sided. 

The girlfriend might not see it as a power play, but the author is arguing that it's a tactic to make him give in. The author's frustration is about the perceived manipulation, and the girlfriend's response is that it's a difference of opinion. 

From a general perspective, using sex as a conditional offer can be problematic if it creates a power imbalance or if one person feels pressured. Consent should be enthusiastic and mutual, not based on trade-offs that one party feels they can't refuse. The author's point is that he's being asked to sacrifice his own time (playing games before she arrives) for a benefit that's only for her. However, the girlfriend might see it as a fair exchange where she's giving up sex for his not playing games during their time together. 

But the author is arguing that the benefit isn't mutual because the time before she arrives is his own, and the offer is only about during their time together. So if he gives up playing any games all day (including before she arrives) to have sex during their time together, it's a one-sided exchange. The girlfriend might not see it that way, but the author feels it's a power play because she's using sex to get him to comply with her terms. 

In terms of right or wrong, it's about whether the girlfriend's actions are manipulative or not. If she's using sex as a bargaining chip to get him to do what she wants, then it's a power play. The author is justified in feeling that way if he doesn't agree to such terms. On the other hand, if the girlfriend is just making an offer and the author is refusing it, then he isn't in the wrong. The question is whether the girlfriend's offer is a power play. The author's perspective is that it is, and he's not okay with it. 

So, considering all that, the author isn't in the wrong because he's expressing his discomfort with the perceived manipulation. It's a difference in how they view the situation, and the author is standing up for his boundaries. Therefore, the answer should be B (No, the author is not in the wrong).
